title: 110_s3341
content: The Act titled "Federal Financial Assistance Management Improvement Act of 2008" is being reauthorized by amending Section 11 of the Act from 1999. The sunset provision is removed, and the Act will not cease to be effective after 8 years. Additionally, a website related to federal grants is established. The Federal Financial Assistance Management Improvement Act of 1999 is amended to include a new subsection (e) requiring the Director to establish a public website for Federal grant applicants. The website must include grant announcements, eligibility statements, application requirements, and grant purposes. The Federal Financial Assistance Management Improvement Act of 1999 is amended to require the establishment of a public website for Federal grant applicants. The website will provide information on grant purposes, funding agencies, deadlines, and allow applicants to search for grants, apply, manage, and report on the use of grants. The Federal Financial Assistance Management Improvement Act of 1999 is amended to require the establishment of a public website for Federal grant applicants, providing information on grant purposes, funding agencies, deadlines, and allowing applicants to search for grants, apply, manage, and report on the use of grants. Subsection (g) is amended to specify exceptions for actions related to establishing the required website. The Federal Financial Assistance Management Improvement Act of 1999 is amended to require the establishment of a public website for Federal grant applicants, providing information on grant purposes, funding agencies, deadlines, and allowing applicants to search for grants, apply, manage, and report on the use of grants. Section 7 is amended to evaluate the implementation of the Act. The Director must submit a report to Congress every 2 years regarding the implementation of the Federal Financial Assistance Management Improvement Act of 2008. The report should include lists of grants, Federal agencies providing financial assistance, and agencies involved in the process. The Director must submit a report to Congress every 2 years on the implementation of the Federal Financial Assistance Management Improvement Act of 2008. The report includes lists of compliant Federal agencies, descriptions of their compliance extent, exempted agencies with explanations and certifications, and common application forms. The Director must provide a report to Congress every 2 years on the implementation of the Federal Financial Assistance Management Improvement Act of 2008, including lists of compliant Federal agencies, descriptions of their compliance extent, exempted agencies with explanations and certifications, and common application forms and reporting requirements for non-Federal entities. The Director must report to Congress every 2 years on the implementation of the Federal Financial Assistance Management Improvement Act of 2008, including efforts to collaborate with non-Federal entities, work with Federal agencies to meet the Act's goals, and identify systems for disbursing Federal financial assistance. Subsequent reports must also include these details. The Director must report to Congress every 2 years on the progress of the Federal Government in meeting the goals of the Federal Financial Assistance Management Improvement Act of 2008 and implementing the strategic plan. This includes evaluating the progress of each Federal agency towards implementing the plan and compiling reports submitted during the applicable period. The "applicable period" for reporting under the Federal Financial Assistance Management Improvement Act of 2008 is defined as the most recent full fiscal year before the report for the first submission, and for subsequent reports, it is the period between the date of the most recent report and the current report. SEC. 5. STRATEGIC PLAN. The Federal Financial Assistance Management Improvement Act of 1999 is amended to include a new section on strategic planning. The Director must submit a strategic plan to Congress within 18 months of the Federal Financial Assistance Management Improvement Act of 2008 enactment. The plan identifies suitable federal financial assistance programs for common applications and reporting forms, common aspects of multiple programs, and any necessary changes in law to achieve the Act's goals. The Act aims to develop an electronic system for managing Federal financial assistance, allowing for online application, tracking, reporting, and certification of funds. The Act aims to streamline Federal financial assistance management by ensuring compliance, creating common applications, and establishing standardized reporting forms for various programs across different Federal agencies. The Act aims to streamline Federal financial assistance management by creating common applications, establishing standardized reporting forms, ensuring compatibility between Federal and State systems, and developing common certifications for programs with similar purposes. The Act aims to streamline Federal financial assistance management by creating common applications, establishing standardized reporting forms, ensuring compatibility between Federal and State systems, and developing common certifications for programs with similar purposes. The Director consults with non-Federal entities and Federal agencies to develop and implement a strategic plan. Federal agencies must develop a plan within 6 months to carry out their responsibilities under the strategic plan. The Federal agency must have clear performance objectives, timelines, and measures to improve communication with non-Federal entities during the implementation of the Act. Consultation with non-Federal entities is required during the development and implementation of the agency's plan. Reporting must be done within 2 years for agencies without exemptions. The Federal agency must report on its progress every 2 years in achieving the objectives of its plan under the Federal Financial Assistance Management Improvement Act of 2008. Additionally, a technical amendment is made to the Act regarding reporting requirements. Passed the Senate on September 22, 2008. Attest: NANCY ERICKSON, Secretary.
